conclusion: To determine if the two cars will collide, we need to analyze the velocity-time graphs of the car and the truck.
The car applies emergency brakes, and the truck continues at a constant speed.
The graph for the car (a) shows a downward slope, indicating deceleration. The graph for the truck (b) shows a horizontal line, indicating constant speed.
The car is traveling at 30 m/s, and the truck is traveling at 10 m/s.
Since the car is initially moving faster than the truck, the relative velocity between the two cars is the difference between their initial speeds.
The relative velocity is 30 m/s - 10 m/s = 20 m/s. This means the cars will collide when the relative velocity is 20 m/s.
Since the relative velocity is 20 m/s, the cars will collide when the car's graph intersects the truck's graph at this point.
The intersection point on the graph occurs at 3 seconds.
Since the intersection point is at 3 seconds, the cars will collide at this time.
